Title: Fundamental theorem of Algebra using fundamental groups.
Content: I tried to prove the fundamental theorem of algebra using fundamental groups. I am not able to understand the proof. Can anyone help me?
AcceptedAnswer: We'll first prove the easier statement that there exists at least one root, which is the one in your book, but we can do better than that. Assume to the contrary that $f$ has no roots in $\Bbb{C}$ . We can therefore construct the following function $g_r(s): I \to S^1$ for each $r \in \Bbb{R}$ : $$g_r(s) = \frac{f(re^{2\pi is})/f(r)}{|f(re^{2\pi is})/f(r)|}$$ Notice how $g_r(0) = g_r(1) = 1$ and it is continuous, so it forms a closed loop in $S^1$ , whose fundamental group we know to be isomorphic to the infinite group generated by a single generator, i.e. $\mathbb{Z}$ . We also know, however that $g_r(s) = g(r,s)$ is continuous in $r$ , so as $r$ varies we get a homotopy between $g_r(s)$ and $g_{0}(s)$ given by $H_r(s,t) = g_{tr}(s)$ . But $g_0(s) = \frac{f(0)/f(0)}{|f(0)/f(0)|} = 1$ , and is therfore constant, and a constant loop is the class of $0 \in \pi_1(S^1)$ , implying $[g_r] = 0$ . Now lets fix some $r_0 >\max( \sum |a_i|,1)$ . For all $x$ on the circle of radius $r_0$ (i.e., $|x| = r_0$ ) we have the following: $$|x^n| = r_0^n = r_0\cdot r_0^{n-1} > (\sum |a_i|)|x^{n-1}| \geq |a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_1x + a_0|$$ Because $|x^n| > t|a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_1x + a_0|$ for $0 \leq t \leq 1$ , the polynomial $$f_t(x) = x^n + t(a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_1x + a_0)$$ has no roots on the circle of radius $r_0$ . And we can define the homotopy: $$g_{r_0,t}(s):= \frac{f_t(r_0e^{2\pi is})/f_t(r_0)}{|f_t(r_0e^{2\pi is})/f_t(r_0)|}$$ Lets notice that $g_{r_0,1} = g_{r_0}$ and $g_{r_0,0} = \omega_n$ , the loop that winds $n$ times around the origin, because $$g_{r_0,0}(s) = \frac{r_0^ne^{2\pi nis}/r_0^n}{|r_0^n/r_0^n|} = e^{2\pi nis} ,\;\text{for } s\in[0,1]$$ And this is an homotop between $ g_{r_0,1}$ and $\omega_n$ . Finally we have that $[\omega_n] = [g_{r_0,1}] = [g_{r_0}] = 0$ but this implies $n=0$ , contrary to assumption that $f$ is non constant. The stronger proof simply follows from using $f'(x) = f(x)/(x-c)$ given the root $c$ found in the prequel until the degree of the polynomial is 0. I've tried to flesh out all of the details in order to guide through the proof as much as possible. If there's anything I can clarify let me know.
